abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health System
            Strengthening and Response to Epidemiological Emergencies
            Project for Nicaragua were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: emergency projects like this one need to be kept
            simple, flexible and focused on solving the problem.
            Therefore the Bank needs to ensure that procurement policies
            can be used flexibly, and that decisions can be made
            efficiently. This operation had some problems with timing.
            The project was able to compensate for the time lost,
            because of its focus on building long-term capacity for
            surveillance and prevention. The monitoring and results
            framework was succinct and appropriate for the emergency
            operation and covered all development objectives. The
            project design will have benefitted from including a
            thorough economic analysis, as well as an impact analysis
            with data on treatment, service utilization, and
            effectiveness of the surveillance system. The results
            framework reflects mostly outputs from project activities,
            and quantitative data on the status and effectiveness of the
            surveillance system was not routinely available for
            inclusion in this report. This lesson should be taken into
            account for the design of similar projects, where one of the
            main goals is to build surveillance capacity.
